intro.title: Hey YOU! Yes you.
intro.content: This seems to be your first time around! Welcome to Ottagon! Let us now meet Judy, your new virtual friend.

intro.title: Hi! I'm Judy.
intro.content: I'm a civil engineer and I work at Ottagon Inc. together with my colleagues Matthew, Phillip, and Sarah as well as my boss Mrs. Collela. I'm a very busy person and I get a lot of emails every day.

intro.title: Today is my birthday!
intro.content: I am off work and I am not checking my emails. I need your help sorting them!

intro.title: You're ready to start!
intro.content: In this first level you'll be presented with 10 emails. Your task is to have a look at them and press either the “trusted” or “spam” button. For this level no prior knowledge is needed. Let’s start whenever you’re comfortable and ready!

training.title: Great! You made it through the first challenge!
training.content: At this point you might have figured out that Ottagon is a platform to train you to deal with phishing attacks. Not just any type of phishing attacks but so called spear-phishing attacks. Let's start with a quick definition provided by chatGPT to understand the nature of spear-phishing.

training.title: Phishing vs. Spear-Phishing
training.content:
Phishing is a broad term for cyber attacks where attackers cast a wide net by sending deceptive emails or messages to trick individuals into revealing sensitive information or performing certain actions. In contrast, spear-phishing is a targeted form of phishing where attackers customize their attacks to specific individuals or groups, making the messages more convincing and increasing the likelihood of success.
— chatGPT

training.title: How am I at risk?
training.content:
You would become the target of a spear-phishing cyber attack if you for example know about sensitive information that in the wrong hands could cause harm to your company, school, or even your personal life.

Just like a spear in the past would've killed one specific fish, a spear-phishing attack is targeted at one specific person or group. That person could be you!

training.title: Training Session: Welcome
training.content: Here on the Ottagon platform you act on behalf of Judy. She is the fictional character you read about at the beginning. Instead of putting your personal email inbox at risk, Ottagon provides you with a virtual, fun experience to learn how to protect yourself against spear-phishing attacks in the real world.

training.title: Training Session: Overview
training.content:
Here are the two key things you will learn in this training session.

  • You will get to know more about Judy

  • You will learn the basics on how to spot a spear-phishing email

Let's start with the first one!

training.title: Hi again! I'm Judy.
training.content:
In order to figure out if an email is genuine or not it is of course important for you to know who I am and who sends emails to me.

Let's start with a quick introduction of myself.

training.title: About me, my job, and my life.
training.content:
I am a civil engineer and I work at Ottagon Inc. together with my colleagues Matthew, Phillip, and Sarah as well as my boss Mrs. Collela. Sometimes I also work with Jennifer or David if we have bigger projects that span across multiple departments.

I am also a very active person. I love to go hiking and I have a cat and a dog at home.

training.title: My schedule and my inbox.
training.content:
At all times you will have access to my weekly schedule. I hope it will help you in the process of figuring out if an email is suspicious or not.
I mostly get emails from my colleagues. Sometimes I of course get messages from other people or organizations, but take caution with emails from senders I do not recognize!

Now that you know a bit more about me, let's move on to the second part of this training session.

training.title: Back to spear-phishing.
training.content:
There are some characteristics of spear-phishing emails that you should be aware of and that can help you identify them.

Let's have a look.

training.title: Look out for these:
training.content:
• Check the senders identity: Sometimes even small spelling mistakes in the senders display name or email address can be a hint
  • Urgency: Spear-phishing mails often ask you to act promptly
  • Personal information: Be very cautious if someone asks for a lot of data or personal information

training.title: ... and look out for these as well:
training.content:
• Relationships: Does Judy know the sender and if not why would that person want to engage with her?
  • Long term attacks: Some adversaries send harmless emails first before they ask for information later on
  • Hacked accounts: Although an email appears to come from a genuine email address does not mean the owner of that address is the person sending the email

training.title: Links and attachments.
training.content: And as with phishing and spam mails in general: You should always be careful with links and attachments as they can point to or contain harmful contents.

training.title: Tools at your fingertips.
training.content:
While you explore Ottagon, you will always have access to the following tools:
  • Judy's schedule (bottom left corner)
  • Training material (top right corner)
  • All emails in the inbox
You can always click on any email you would like to read and do not have to follow the order of the emails. Pro tip: Sometimes reading a few more emails can help you to better understand the context of the email you are currently viewing.

training.title: You're good to proceed!
training.content:
Now that you know what to look out for, let's move on to the next challenge! Of course, you will always have access to this training material again from the top right corner of the platform.

Let's go!

end.title: That's it for today!
end.content:
Thank you so much! You finished the first session of this training. You will get a reminder to come back here by email next week.

— Roman

You can now close Ottagon.
